awd_titl_txt: EAPSI:Design of Polite Service Robots with Human-Like Approaching Behavior
awd_abstract_narration:
This award will study how and when robots should approach humans to initiate an interaction. The objective is to have the robots understand who needs their help, and how to make themselves politely available to the user. The methodology of the work is a combination of analysis, research, development and experimentation. The project will be conducted in collaboration with Dr. Chi-Sheng Shih at National Taiwan University in Taipei, Taiwan, where the lab already has the capable robots to achieve the outlined functions. Robotics is an extremely important field that will shape human life in the future. The physical presence of robots and their ability to manipulate their physical environment provides both unlimited potential and extreme challenges. Without developing the user experience with robots, humans will not be able to benefit from their powerful potential. Findings of this study can be used to facilitate the design of different classes of robots such as elderly-care robots or to help children with autism and other needs. 

The importance of this work stems in the integration of robots in human environments; especially if the humans are regular non-technical people who wouldn?t be sure how to interact or get help from a robot. By designing the proposed model on how to approach humans, an entire subfield of Robotics called Service Robots is improved. Service robots aim to act as receptionists or as points-of-direction in settings such as hotels, malls, etc. 

This award under the East Asia and Pacific Summer Institutes program supports summer research by a U.S. graduate student and is jointly funded by NSF and the Ministry of Science and Technology of Taiwan.

por.por_cntn:
The project I undertook concerned the design and operation of robots. There are many kinds of robots such as Quadcopters and Humanoids, however my work was so fundamental that it could potentially apply to all sorts of robots. This was very important because I targeted generalizability when doing my research.

The research addresses the question of how to design intelligent robots without programming everything into them. That is, the robot must be capable of learning. Intelligent robots should have the capability to commit mistakes and learn from them, enabling them to take better decisions at subsequent times. The kind of robotic system I hope to design is one that evolves vertically and horizontally. This means that the robot should be able to acquire new skills, learn how to do new things; as well as become better at doing things it already knows how to do.

For those reasons, I laid a set of principles to guide the design of robots, and outlined techniques to realize these designs. Futhermore, I designed experiments to evaluate these propositions. If they are endorsed, the approach I define can transform and reshape the field of robotics.

In the broader sense, the research has the potential to create economic opportunities by leveraging the technological superiority of the designs. It can also fundamentally change the way we, as a general public, perceive and interact with robots, and technology overall. For example, if we can design robots that teach themeselves how to walk, they will be able coexist in our environment. There are many aspects to which this fundamental approach can be applied to.

This is what I worked on, and produced, during the Summer at National Taiwan University.
